baseline_groups.claim_summary: The 2001 HSR Act Amendment, which exempted small mergers from premerger notification, caused an increase in horizontal (same-industry) mergers among newly-exempt firms relative to non-horizontal mergers and relative to never-exempt firms. The triple DID coefficient on post*horizontal*below in log merger counts is 0.218, implying a ~24% increase.
baseline_groups.notes: Table 1, Column 2. Coefficient 0.218 (SE 0.050, t=4.33, p<0.001). N=72, R2=0.997. Triple difference-in-differences with year, year*below, and year*horizontal fixed effects. This is the paper's main result.

baseline_groups.claim_summary: Within newly-exempt mergers only (dropping the never-exempt comparison group), the DID of post*horizontal on log merger counts is 0.186, confirming that horizontal mergers increased relative to non-horizontal mergers after the amendment among newly-exempt firms.
baseline_groups.notes: Table 1 implied specification. Coefficient 0.186 (SE 0.046, t=4.06, p<0.001). N=36, R2=0.988. DID on newly-exempt subsample with year FE. This is a supporting baseline that drops the never-exempt control group to show the within-group effect.

global_notes: Paper is 'Stealth Consolidation: Evidence from an Amendment to the Hart-Scott-Rodino Act' by Thomas Wollmann (AER: Insights). The data consists of merger counts aggregated to 72 observations (18 years x 2 exemption groups x 2 merger types). The main identification is a triple DID: post (year>2001) x horizontal (same 4-digit SIC) x below (newly-exempt). The specification search generates 93 total specifications. Many specs come in triplets: triple-diff, newly-exempt DID, and never-exempt DID (placebo). The never-exempt specs are classified as non-core placebo tests since they verify the control group shows no effect. Dollar-value outcome specs, horizontal-only DDs, non-horizontal-only DDs, horizontal share DD, and total mergers DD are classified as non-core because they use different outcome variables or fundamentally different treatment structures. Software-only heterogeneity analyses and placebo timing tests are also non-core. All sample restrictions (excl. software, excl. large mergers, time windows, post-period redefinitions, LOO), functional form changes (levels, Poisson, IHS, first differences), FE/controls variations (linear/quadratic trends), inference changes (classical SE), and weighting (WLS) are classified as core when applied to the triple-diff or newly-exempt DID.
